content: fly fishing gloves by barbara hurd these tightly knit fingerless gloves were designed for fly-fishermen to keep the water out hands warm and fingers free they should be made out of wool so if they do go in the water they will still keep the hands warm for increases i used m1r and m1l to create tight seams aiding in water protection gauge 20 sts /4 in 10cm with firm hand slightly tighter than for a garment 29 row per 4in/10cm in height size one size fits most men fits wrist circumference 6 75-8in/17-20cm needles single pointed 5us 3 75mm or size to get gauge yarn worsted weight yarn approx 200 yards/1 83m notions large-eyed sewing needle 10in/25cm piece of contrasting yarn to be used as a soft stitch holder markers stitch holders m1r insert left needle from back to front under the strand before the next stitch then knit into the front of this strand one stitch increase made m1l insert left needle from front to back under the strand before the next stitch then knit into the back of this strand one stitch increase made helpful hints in the beginning use your hand for a model even if the gloves aren t for you simply adjust larger or smaller for the recipient but the basic placement of fingers is the same on all sizes after completing the first glove use it as the model to insure gloves of equal size some people prefer one to be larger than the other since our hands vary do what pleases you whenever putting stitches on needles try to keep the stitches per needle approximately even in number when knitting the fingers use 4 needles total 3 to hold the stitches and one for the working needle more than that creates a tangled mess use the contrasting yarn rather than stitch holders to hold the hand stitches use non-yarn stitch holders for holding finger stitches only this aids in the ease of making the fingers non-yarn holders can create a tangled mess if used on the hand left glove cast on 40 stitches evenly on 4 needles pm place marker and join *k1 p1 around until 3 inches/7 5 cm change to stockinette stitch all knit and knit 5 rounds row 1 after the marker m1r k1 m1l pm place second marker one time only finish knitting round row 2 knit repeat row 1 and 2 until you have 13 stitches between markers end having just completed row 2 next row remove marker place all 13 stitches on a needle holder for thumb remove second marker cast on one stitch pm place marker this will be the new beginning of the row cast on one stitch knit 15 stitches pm place marker this will mark the start of the pinkie and finish round you should have 16 stitches from the start of the row to the start of the pinkie or second marker we will work on it later knit for 1
